Chapter 1 – Balance Sheet Principles
A balance sheet reports a company’s assets, liabilities, and equity at a point in time...
Key sections include Current Assets, Fixed Assets, Current Liabilities, Long‑Term Liabilities, and Shareholder’s Equity.
Important concepts: double‑entry accounting, accounting equation (Assets = Liabilities + Equity), accrual vs. cash basis, classification of assets and liabilities, depreciation methods, and equity components (common stock, retained earnings).

slides.title: Accounting Equation
slides.html_body:
Accounting Equation

Assets = Liabilities + Equity. This fundamental relationship ensures that a company’s resources are balanced by its obligations and owners’ claims.

slides.title: Assets – Current vs. Fixed
slides.html_body:
Assets – Current vs. Fixed

Current assets are cash or will become cash within one year (e.g., inventory). Fixed assets are long‑term resources such as property, plant, and equipment.

slides.title: Liabilities – Current vs. Long‑Term
slides.html_body:
Liabilities – Current vs. Long‑Term

Current liabilities are obligations due within one year (e.g., accounts payable). Long‑term liabilities extend beyond one year (e.g., bonds payable).

slides.title: Shareholder’s Equity Components
slides.html_body:
Shareholder’s Equity

Includes common stock, preferred stock, additional paid‑in capital, and retained earnings.

slides.title: Double‑Entry Principle
slides.html_body:
Double‑Entry Principle

Every transaction affects at least two accounts, keeping the accounting equation in balance.

slides.title: Accrual vs. Cash Basis
slides.html_body:
Accrual vs. Cash Basis

Accrual accounting records revenues and expenses when earned or incurred, while cash basis records them when cash changes hands.

slides.title: Depreciation Methods
slides.html_body:
Depreciation Methods

Common methods include straight‑line, declining‑balance, and units‑of‑production.

slides.title: Classification of Accounts
slides.html_body:
Classification of Accounts

Accounts are grouped into assets, liabilities, equity, revenues, and expenses for reporting.

slides.title: Balance Sheet Structure
slides.html_body:
Balance Sheet Structure

Presented as Assets on the left, Liabilities and Equity on the right, or in a vertical format.

slides.title: Equity Reporting
slides.html_body:
Equity Reporting

Shows changes in owners’ equity over the period, including net income and dividends.
